abstract.p: Article recounts popularity of World Series as conversation topic among workers in New York's financial district (S)

block.p: Even as stock prices fluctuate, thoughts on Wall Street have turned from the Big Board to the Big Diamond.
The World Series battle between the Yankees and Mets -- the first Subway Series in 44 years -- has been dominating conversations on the trading floors and elsewhere in New York's financial district.
Even as stock prices fluctuate, thoughts on Wall Street have turned from the Big Board to the Big Diamond.
The World Series battle between the Yankees and Mets -- the first Subway Series in 44 years -- has been dominating conversations on the trading floors and elsewhere in New York's financial district.

''I happened to visit the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and as I walked by, 60 to 70 percent of the groups of people were talking about the Mets and Yankees,'' Bill Allyn, director of principal trading for Jefferies & Company, said in an interview with Bloomberg last week. ''They're talking about the cost of the tickets and the times of the games.''
With games expected to run late into the night, ''traders are going to have to get used to operating on a little less sleep,'' added Mr. Allyn, a Chicago native and a White Sox fan.

Andrew Forman, an analyst at UBS Warburg, could not get baseball out of his mind, as some of its customers learned. In a recent investment report, he jokingly offered theories for last week's downturn in specialty-drug stocks: ''Concern that earnings are slowing, a preference for computer shares, the need to raise money to buy World Series tickets.''
Mr. Forman likened the Mets to the specialty-drug industry: Both were born in the 1960's and are underdogs taking on old-timers.
